description: From Middle English preserven, from Old French preserver, from Medieval Latin prēservāre (“keep, preserve”), from Late Latin praeservāre (“guard beforehand”), from prae (“before”, adverb) +‎ servāre (“maintain, keep”).

entries.meaning: A sweet spread made of any of a variety of fruits.

examples: Suppose Shakespeare had been knocked on the head some dark night in Sir Thomas Lucy's preserves, the world would have wagged on better or worse, the pitcher gone to the well, the scythe to the corn, and the student to his book; and no one been any the wiser of the loss.

verbs.description: preserve (third-person singular simple present preserves, present participle preserving, simple past and past participle preserved)

entries.meaning: To protect; to keep from harm or injury.
examples: Every people have the right to preserve its identity and culture.

entries.meaning: To save from decay by the use of some preservative substance, such as sugar or salt; to season and prepare (fruits, meat, etc.) for storage.
To maintain throughout; to keep intact.
examples: to preserve appearances; to preserve silence
